Tokens

During interpretation, all scripts are broken down into units called tokens for processing.
The boundary between one token and the next varies depending on the type of token.

Bare Words

A "bare word" is a specific sequence of characters written directly in a script that is not enclosed in "" or '' quotes.
Bare words follow these rules:

  • They consist of lowercase and uppercase letters, '_' (underscore), numbers, and so-called full-width characters. However, a number cannot be at the beginning.
  • The sequence is treated as a single "bare word" until it ends.


Example:
    ampan  // OK
    123a // NG because it starts with a number
    _asdf // OK because an underscore can be at the beginning
    continue // This is a reserved word (OK)
    FullWidthCharacters // So-called full-width characters are OK as a "bare word"

Bare words are further classified into reserved words and identifiers.

Reserved Words

Reserved words are the following and are not identifiers. Any bare word that is not a reserved word is an identifier.

break continue const catch class case
debugger default delete do extends export
enum else function finally false for
global getter goto incontextof Infinity
invalidate instanceof isvalid import int in
if NaN null new octet protected property
private public return real synchronized switch
static setter string super typeof throw
this true try void var while with

These reserved words each have a special meaning for important purposes in constructing the script's grammar. Some of these are used as operators.
However, not all of these reserved words are used in the current version.

Identifiers

"Identifiers" are all bare words that are not reserved words. These are used for variable, function, and class names that the developer can name freely.
Even if an identifier contains a reserved word, as long as it is not exactly a reserved word, it will be recognized as an identifier rather than a reserved word.

Symbols

Symbols are also broken down as tokens. The following symbols exist:

>>>= >>> >>= >> >= > <<= <=
<-> << < === == => = !== != !
&&= && &= & ||=
|| |= | ... . ++ += + -= -- - *=
* /= / \= \ %= % ^= ^ [ ] ( ) ~
? : , ; { } # $

These are extracted as tokens based on the longest match. For example, ++ is broken down as a single symbol ++, not as + and +. If you want to write them as separate + and +, you must insert a space between them.

Each symbol has an important meaning as an element constructing the grammar. Among the symbols, several are used as operators.

Numeric Literals

Numeric literals are those that begin with a digit or a . (decimal point). TJS2 recognizes the following formats.
Writing a number normally results in a decimal numeric literal.

Example:
    0
    3.1
    342.3
    1

For decimals, you can also use e or E to provide an exponent specification with base 10. e and E have the same meaning.

Example:
    1e-3   // 1×10-3
    3.4e10   // 3.4×1010
    9.3E-2  // 9.3×10-2

Prefixing with 0x or 0X specifies a hexadecimal number. 0x and 0X have the same meaning.

Example:
    0x1234
    0Xff
    0x3f33

Prefixing with 0b or 0B specifies a binary number.

Example:
    0b0100
    0B0010100010100001

A leading 0 causes the number to be treated as an octal number.

Example:
    01234
    033

Decimal points and exponent specification using p are also possible for hexadecimal, octal, and binary. p is an exponent specification with base 2.

Example:
    0b1.1    // Represents 1.5 via 1 + 1/2
    0x2.f    // Represents 2.9375 via 2 + 15/16
    0x1p8    // Represents 256.0 via 1 × 28


A numeric literal is treated as a single token as long as it consists of characters that form a numeric literal.

String Literals

String literals are enclosed in "" (double quotes) or '' (single quotes). You may use either double quotes or single quotes.
However, within "" (double quotes), you do not need to escape ' (single quotes) with \, and within '' (single quotes), you do not need to escape " (double quotes) with \.

Example:
    "this is a string."
    'this is also a string.'
    "Can't use without a quotation."

The \ (backslash) character has a special meaning within a string. The meaning changes depending on the character that follows the \. Providing a special specification following a \ is called escaping.


\\    : The \ mark itself
\'    : ' (Single quote)
\"    : " (Double quote)
\a    : BEL (Audible bell)
\b    : BS (Backspace)
\f    : FF (Form feed)
\n    : LF (Line feed)
\r    : CR (Carriage return)

\t    : HT (Horizontal tab)
\v    : VT (Vertical tab)
\xH   : H=Hexadecimal ( H represents the character code )
\XH   : Same as above

In the \xH format, a hexadecimal number is specified in the H part. This hexadecimal number is then treated as a character code and replaced with that single character.


Example:
    'Can\'t help'  ( using \' )
    "\x1234"     ( Character with the code 0x1234 as a wide character )

In addition, for the \xH format, as long as characters that form a hexadecimal number (0-9, A-F, a-f) follow \x, they are considered part of the H portion. However, a maximum of 4 digits are recognized in environments where the wide character size is 16-bit, and up to 8 digits on 32-bit machines (16-bit for Windows, 32-bit for Linux and Solaris).
If you write "\x22An Apple", the beginning will be interpreted as \x22A. To avoid this, write it as "\x22" "An Apple" to separate the strings. In TJS, consecutive string literals like this are treated as a single string.

For strings, please also refer to String Operations.

@-prefixed String Literals

Placing an @ before a string literal causes content between & and ; or between ${ and } within that string literal to be treated as an expression, and the result of evaluating it will be expanded there (if you write an expression between & and ; or ${ and }, the result is embedded there).
If you do not want to expand & or $, you can place a \ before the & or $ to prevent expansion.


Example:
    @"1+2=&1+2;"  ( Results in the string "1+2=3" )
    @"Content of variable f is &f;"  ( Expands the content of variable f at the position of &f; )
    @"Result of calling func is &func();"  ( Any valid expression can be written between & and ; )
    @"Result of calling func is ${func()}"  ( Same as above )
    @"true \&\& false is &true && false;"  ( Writing \ before & prevents & from expanding )

Expressions written here can access variables and other entities (including local variables) within the scope accessible from where the string literal is written.

Octet Stream Literals

Octet stream literals are enclosed in <% and %>, allowing you to write octet data (binary data) inside them.
Data is specified as multiple two-digit hexadecimal numbers separated by spaces or other characters.

Example:
    <% 00 01 02 03 %>
    <% ff ff ff 00 04 0f ff 30 %>

For octet streams, please also refer to Octet Stream Operations.

Regular Expression Patterns

Regular expression patterns are enclosed in / and /, allowing you to write a regular expression pattern inside.
Flag characters can be written following the regular expression pattern: g is the global search flag (matches all occurrences; without this flag, it matches only the first), i is the flag to ignore case, and l is the flag to perform localized collation.
Regular expression patterns written this way are treated as objects of the RegExp class.

Example:
    /[0-9]-[0-9]-[0-9]/
    /^;\s*(.*?)\s*=(.*)$/
    /start(.*?)end/gi

For regular expression patterns, please also refer to the RegExp Class.
